title: Tight-binding quantum chemical molecular dynamics simulation of mechano-chemical reactions during chemical–mechanical polishing process of SiO2 surface by CeO2 particle
abstract: Our tight-binding quantum chemical molecular dynamics method was applied to the investigations on the mechano-chemical reaction dynamics during the chemical–mechanical polishing (CMP) process of SiO2 surface by CeO2 particle. The mechanical forces introduced by the CeO2 particle were found to accelerate the chemical reactions at the CeO2–SiO2 interface. The time profile of the bond population and atomic charges reveals the mechanism of the mechano-chemical reaction dynamics during the CMP process. The electronic states change from Ce4+ to Ce3+ was observed during the CMP process and this reduction reaction is related to the specific characteristics of the Ce element, which has two oxidation states, Ce3+ and Ce4+. Finally, we concluded that our tight-binding quantum chemical molecular dynamics method is an effective tool to clarify the mechano-chemical reaction dynamics during the CMP process, because these investigations cannot be realized by the conventional first-principles calculation and classical molecular dynamics method.

sections.Introduction:
1
                  Introduction
                  Chemical–mechanical polishing (CMP) has proven to be the only viable technique to achieve global planarization for interlevel dielectric and damascene processes in the deep sub-micron multilevel interconnect fabrication [1,2]. The desired surface is generated by polishing materials at atomic level with the combined effect of mechanical forces and chemical reactions [3]. The CMP is expected to solve various problems related to the surface roughness in semiconductor devices. In particular, it is well known that only the CMP process enables the fabrication of damascene interconnection architectures, which cannot be realized by other planarization techniques. One of the key issues in the CMP is the development of slurries that provide high polishing rate, good planarity, and high selectivity [4]. Abrasive particles for the CMP applications are primarily centered on silica, alumina and ceria. For example, Hoshino et al. investigated the CMP process of silica surface using ceria-containing slurry by experimental methods [5]. However, significant gaps still exist in the experimental phenomena and fundamental understanding of the specific role of interfacial reactions between the ceria slurry and silica surface.
                  Hence, in the present study we applied our original tight-binding quantum chemical molecular dynamics method to the investigations on the CMP mechanism of the SiO2 surface by CeO2 particle. Especially, the mechano-chemical reaction dynamics at the SiO2 and CeO2 interface in the CMP process was focused on atomic and electronic level. These investigations cannot be realized by the conventional first-principles calculation and classical molecular dynamics method.

sections.Conclusions:
4
                  Conclusions
                  We successfully applied our tight-binding quantum chemical molecular dynamics method to the investigations on the CMP process of SiO2 surface by CeO2 particle. Not only the atomistic phenomena such as bond-breaking and bond-formation but also electronic states dynamics and electron transfer dynamics during the mechano-chemical reactions were clarified and discussed. The mechanical forces introduced by the CeO2 particle were found to accelerate the chemical reactions at the CeO2–SiO2 interface. The electronic states change from Ce4+ to Ce3+ was observed and this reduction reaction is related to the specific characteristics of the Ce element, which has two oxidation states, Ce3+ and Ce4+. These results indicate that our tight-binding quantum chemical molecular dynamics method is a very effective tool to clarify the mecahno-chemical reaction dynamics during the CMP process.
